page.text: Leo Birmingham Parkway at North Beacon Street,
Road Safety Audit—Leo Birmingham Parkway at North Beacon Street, Brighton

text.a: Safety Issue #2: Lack of Pedestrian and Bicycle Accommodations.................................................... 8

page.text: Road Safety Audit—Leo Birmingham Parkway at North Beacon Street, Brighton
The Road Safety Audit at Leo Birmingham Parkway at North Beacon Street in the Brighton
neighborhood of Boston was conducted because the intersection is a High Crash Location located just
north of a bridge rehabilitation project on I-90 eastbound and westbound over US Route 20 (North
Beacon Street (Bridge No. B-16-060, MassDOT Project No. 606770). As part of the bridge rehabilitation
project, safety improvements to the intersection of Leo Birmingham Parkway/North Beacon Street are
being considered, particularly along the North Beacon Street northbound approach to the intersection,
which runs under the I-90 overpass. Thirty-five crashes were reported at the intersection of Leo
Birmingham Parkway/North Beacon Street from 2011-2015, including 10 injury crashes.
The Road Safety Audit was conducted on Thursday, May 19, 2016 at 9:00 a.m. at WGBH, located at 1
Guest Street in Brighton. Table 1 shows the participating members of the audit.
Crash data was compiled at the intersection for the time period from 2011-2015. During this period, 35
crashes occurred at the intersection, including 11 (or 31%) crashes that resulted in personal injury. Of the
35 crashes, 22 (or 63%) were classified as angle crashes; seven (20%) were single-vehicle crashes; 5
(14%) were rear-rend crashes, and one (3%) was sideswipe crash. Seven (20%) crashes occurred after
dark, and eight (23%) crashes occurred on wet pavement. Larger than expected shares of crashes
occurred involving motorists aged 21-29 years old (40% of all crashes) and during the month of
September (17% of all crashes). Most crashes (62%) occurred during or near peak hours.
Road Safety Audit—Leo Birmingham Parkway at North Beacon Street, Brighton
is an approximately ¾-mile roadway that runs east-west between Soldier’s
Field Road to the west and Market Street to the east. Leo Birmingham Parkway runs north-south between
Market Street and Western Avenue to the north. Leo Birmingham Parkway generally consists of two
lanes in each direction, with the exception of the northbound segment between Market Street and Western
Avenue, which is three to four lanes in the northbound direction. Leo Birmingham Parkway is classified
by MassDOT as an urban principal arterial, and is under the jurisdiction of the Department of
Conservation and Recreation (DCR). The regulatory speed limit on Leo Birmingham Parkway is 30 mph
based on Massachusetts General Laws for roadways through thickly settled areas. Prevailing speeds are
somewhat higher; Massachusetts State Police attending the audit noted that a typical speeding ticket
issued on the roadway is for vehicles traveling at about 45 mph. Sidewalks are not provided along Leo
Birmingham Parkway. A paved shoulder of varying width is typically provided along the right side of the
is a roadway, approximately one mile in length, that typically consists of one travel
lane in each direction, and runs east-west between Leo Birmingham Parkway to the west and Cambridge
Street/Brighton Avenue to the east. At Leo Birmingham Parkway, the road curves such that it intersects
Leo Birmingham Parkway from the southeast. North Beacon Street is classified by MassDOT as an
urban principal arterial, and is under the jurisdiction of the City of Boston. The regulatory speed limit on
North Beacon Street is 30 mph. Sidewalks are provided along both sides of North Beacon Street. Bicycle
accommodations are not provided along North Beacon Street in the vicinity of the study intersection.
The intersection of Leo Birmingham Parkway/North Beacon Street is an unsignalized T-intersection.
Leo Birmingham Parkway eastbound and westbound vehicles each approach the intersection in two all-
purpose travel lanes; no lane use signage or markings are present. The two directions of Leo Birmingham
Parkway is divided by a 20-foot landscaped median The North Beacon Street northbound approach is
unmarked, but is wide enough for three vehicle lanes to form at the stop line. Before the road safety
audit, during the morning peak period, vehicles were observed forming two left-turn lanes and one right-
turn lane. Left-turning vehicles were also observed using the median between the eastbound and
westbound directions of Leo Birmingham Parkway as a refuge area in order to make the left turn in two
stages. Crosswalks and curb ramps are not present at the intersection. Evidence of significant pedestrian
activity (e.g. “goat paths”) was observed in some locations, indicating a pedestrian desire line across Leo
Birmingham Parkway. Sidewalks along North Beacon Street end, without transition, at Leo Birmingham
Parkway. Two MBTA bus stops for the Route #64 bus are located near the intersection: On North
Beacon Street northbound, just south of the intersection, and along Leo Birmingham Parkway westbound,
just west of the intersection. According to MassDOT, it appears these stops are not officially recognized
by the MBTA, though bus stop signs remain. Buses were observed stopping at each of these bus stops.
On the day of the audit, utility work was being performed at the intersection.
Road Safety Audit—Leo Birmingham Parkway at North Beacon Street, Brighton
Road Safety Audit—Leo Birmingham Parkway at North Beacon Street, Brighton

including two left-turn lanes, and stop
well ahead of the stop line in order to

page.text: The following section will identify the safety issues identified at the intersection of Leo Birmingham
Parkway/North Beacon Street and the possible potential safety enhancements discussed during the audit.

i.b: Safety Issue #1: Intersection Control and Geometry

page.text: The intersection of Leo Birmingham Parkway/North Beacon Street
is an unsignalized T-intersection. North Beacon Street northbound
is stop-controlled. Traffic signals at the intersection are
permanently on flash; MassDOT officials attending the RSA noted
that it is unlikely that they could be reprogrammed to act as a full
signal without significant upgrades. Leo Birmingham Parkway is
separated by a 20-foot landscaped median. Vehicles turning left
from the stop-controlled North Beacon Street northbound approach
were observed taking this left turn in two stages, using the median
as a refuge area as they waited for gaps in each direction of
unrestricted-flow traffic. If multiple vehicles cross Leo
Birmingham Parkway eastbound, the second vehicle may be
exposed to oncoming vehicles. Fifteen angle crashes involved
North Beacon Street northbound vehicles and Leo Birmingham
Parkway eastbound vehicles. Additionally, three rear-end crashes
involved Leo Birmingham Parkway eastbound vehicles, caused by vehicles slowing down to yield to
The North Beacon Street northbound approach does not have
any marked travel lanes. The approach widens from one 14-
foot lane south of the I-90 overpass to approximately 80 feet
at the stop line. Vehicles were observed forming three travel
lanes: two left-turn lanes and a right-turn lane. A MassDOT
representative attending the RSA stated that a stop-controlled
approach with two left-turn lanes is an undesirable condition,
as the two adjacent left-turning vehicles block each other’s
view of oncoming traffic. North Beacon Street northbound
vehicles were observed stopping one full vehicle length ahead
of the stop line in order to properly see oncoming eastbound
vehicles. Vehicles were observed forming two left-turn lanes
within the median of Leo Birmingham Parkway, another
undesirable condition. Seven crashes occurred between
vehicles taking left turns onto Leo Birmingham Parkway
Road Safety Audit—Leo Birmingham Parkway at North Beacon Street, Brighton
westbound from North Beacon Street and Leo Birmingham Parkway westbound vehicles. The informal
two left-turn lane condition is also a potential factor in the 15 angle crashes between Leo Birmingham
Parkway eastbound vehicles and North Beacon Street northbound vehicles, as sightlines to the west may
be blocked by an adjacent left-turning vehicle.
Four-lane roadways like Leo Birmingham Parkway are susceptible to “double threat” or “courtesy”
crashes, which occur when a mainline vehicle yields the right-of-way to a left-turning vehicle, which is
subsequently struck by a through vehicle in the adjacent travel lane. Vehicles stopping in the outside
travel lane can block the sight lines of vehicles in the adjacent inside travel lane, preventing them from
The intersection is skewed such that North Beacon Street
intersects Leo Birmingham Parkway from the southeast.
The median opening on Leo Birmingham Parkway is
similarly offset to align with the angle of North Beacon
Street. An RSA team member noted that Leo Birmingham
Parkway westbound vehicles travel most of the way through
the intersection before turning left onto North Beacon
Street, which may cause single-vehicle crashes and rear-end
crashes (though not reflected in the crash data). Since
westbound vehicles proceed past the North Beacon Street
leg of the intersection in order to make a left turn, vehicles
in the North Beacon Street northbound approach may
mistake these left-turning vehicles for through vehicles.
The east leg of Leo Birmingham Parkway slopes downward
toward the intersection, which may result in westbound vehicles traveling faster toward the intersection.
Four single-vehicle crashes occurred along the Leo Birmingham Parkway westbound approach to the
intersection, including one crash where speed was specifically cited as a contributing factor. The slope
may also cause North Beacon Street right-turning vehicles to get up to speed more slowly, which may
result in rear-end crashes (though not specifically reflected in the crash data).
Road Safety Audit—Leo Birmingham Parkway at North Beacon Street, Brighton
1. In the short term, consider striping lane use pavement markings on North Beacon Street to organize
vehicles into a single left-turn lane and a single right-turn lane. Work with Eversource to conduct this
work once current utility work is complete.
2. If lane lines are striped on the North Beacon Street northbound approach to the intersection, consider
the use of dashed lane lines through the intersection from North Beacon Street northbound to Leo
Birmingham Parkway eastbound and westbound so that vehicles can be guided through the intersection
and to discourage the formation of multiple left-turn lanes on the North Beacon Street northbound
3. Consider the safety benefits of enhancing the existing flashing operation at the intersection to increase
visibility and awareness of the intersection.
4. If at least one signal warrant is met, consider a full signalization of the intersection to eliminate
“courtesy crashes” and the need for North Beacon Street northbound vehicles to look for gaps in two
lanes of traffic in either direction. Consider the potential drawbacks of signalization, which may include
the persistence of angle crashes and an increase in rear-end crashes. Consider the costs, safety benefits,
and drawbacks of signalization compared to other enhancements, such as a modern roundabout. If the
intersection is fully signalized, retroreflective backplates should be used to minimize the effects of solar
glare on motorists. A “(Red) Signal Ahead” (W3-3) sign, with illuminated “Red” text when the signal is
red, should be considered in advance of the I-90 overpass on the North Beacon Street northbound
approach, and supplemental signal posts should be placed at the end of the approach.
5. Consider the appropriateness of designating one of the two travel lanes in each direction on Leo
Birmingham Parkway as exclusive turning lanes or auxiliary turning lanes, with appropriate striping and
advanced signage, to reduce the instances of rear-end and single-vehicle crashes as a result of vehicles
unexpectedly slowing to turn at the intersection. If exclusive turn lanes are implemented, consider
modifications to the median and/or shoulders to prevent through movements from these lanes.
6. Consider using striping to visually reduce the turning radius to and from North Beacon Street so that
7. As part of the I-90 Bridge Reconstruction Project, consider realigning the intersection so that North
Beacon Street intersects Leo Birmingham Parkway at a right angle in order to improve sight lines and
reduce the likelihood that vehicles form more lanes than desired. The location of the existing bridge
foundation must be considered. Also consider realigning Leo Birmingham Parkway so that the Leo
Birmingham Parkway eastbound and North Beacon Street northbound approaches form the “mainline” of
the intersection, while the Leo Birmingham Parkway westbound approach forms the “stem” of the T-
intersection. This improvement would formalize the prevailing movements at the intersection as
“through” movements which would not need to yield at the intersection. It should be noted that the
commercial service road north of the intersection is within the DCR layout, and not privately owned.
Road Safety Audit—Leo Birmingham Parkway at North Beacon Street, Brighton
8. As part of long-term design considerations, consider a “road diet” on Leo Birmingham Parkway to
reduce the number of general travel lanes in each direction, reduce travel speeds, and improve pedestrian
and bicycle accommodations along the entire Leo Birmingham Parkway corridor, including at the
intersection. Consider existing traffic volumes, including trucks traveling between Western Avenue and
Electric Avenue, which currently rely on the roadway. Consider parallel roads, including Soldier’s Field
Road and Interstate 90, which may render Leo Birmingham Parkway unnecessary to carry significant
9. As part of long-term design considerations, consider a single-lane modern roundabout at the
intersection to eliminate high-speed angle crashes and improve pedestrian accommodations at the
intersection. Consider drawbacks, such as increased rear-end and sideswipe crashes and lack of audible
pedestrian indications for visually impaired pedestrians. Also consider truck turning movements through
the intersection and the placement of the I-90 bridge foundation, as these will inform the geometry of
Road Safety Audit—Leo Birmingham Parkway at North Beacon Street, Brighton

text.b: including a motel and an MBTA bus

i.b: Safety Issue #2: Lack of Pedestrian and Bicycle Accommodations

page.text: There are limited pedestrian and bicycle accommodations at
the intersection. Sidewalks are not provided on Leo
Birmingham Parkway, and those provided on North Beacon
Street end at the intersection. No curb ramps or crosswalks
are provided. There is demand for pedestrian
accommodations at the intersection as indicated by goat paths
through the median on Leo Birmingham Parkway and along
the north and south sides of the intersection.
There are several pedestrian generators in the vicinity of the
intersection. Several restaurants and retail locations, as well
as a motel, are located north of the intersection, as is the Dr.
Paul Dudley White Bike Path, a popular pedestrian and
bicycle connection to downtown Boston. North Beacon
Street itself is a pedestrian-friendly connection to the core of
Brighton and public transit connections to the rest of the city. Bus stops for the Route #64 bus, which are
not officially recognized by the MBTA, are another pedestrian generator to the area.
Similarly, bicycle accommodations are lacking in the vicinity
of the intersection. Paved shoulders of about 4 feet in width
are provided along Leo Birmingham Parkway. No shoulders
or other pavement markings are provided on the approach or
departure of North Beacon Street. On the day of the RSA, a
detour sign was placed in the shoulder on the eastbound
approach of Leo Birmingham Parkway, forcing bicyclists to
ride in the general travel lanes or on the grass. According to
an RSA team member, bicyclists use Leo Birmingham
Parkway as a connection to the Dr. Paul Dudley White Bike
Path, which is accessible at North Arsenal Street to the
northeast and at Nonantum Road to the west. One crash
involving a bicyclist was reported; both the bicyclist and the
motorist were turning right from Leo Birmingham Parkway
1. Consider providing a formal median refuge area to encourage pedestrians to cross at specific locations
mid-block. Such a location should allow pedestrians to be seen by motorists approaching from any
direction and stop for crossing pedestrians.
2. As part of long-term reconstruction efforts, provide ADA-compliant pedestrian sidewalks, crosswalks,
and pedestrian ramps at the intersection. If the intersection is signalized, provide ADA-compliant audible
Road Safety Audit—Leo Birmingham Parkway at North Beacon Street, Brighton
3. Consider adding a formal pedestrian crossing with a Rectangular Rapid Flash Beacon (RRFB) or High
Intensity Activated Crosswalk (HAWK) at an appropriate location near the pedestrian desire line across
Leo Birmingham Parkway to allow pedestrians to cross Leo Birmingham Parkway safely.
4. Consider formalizing the MBTA bus stops in the vicinity of the intersection. If these stops are
formalized, pedestrian sidewalk connections should be provided to the surrounding neighborhoods. If
these stops are not formalized, they should be removed so that pedestrians are not encouraged to cross
Leo Birmingham Parkway in unsafe locations. Consider impacts to local residents and businesses if these
5. In the short term, provide consistent shoulders along Leo Birmingham Parkway to provide a space for
bicyclists to ride without mixing with vehicular traffic.
6. Consider the appropriateness of reducing lane widths on Leo Birmingham Parkway to about 10 feet to
reduce vehicle speeds and in order to provide a wide, buffered, or separated bicycle lane on Leo
7. Consider providing separated bicycle lanes under the I-90 overpass on North Beacon Street so that
bicyclists have a dedicated space to ride.
8. As part of long-term design considerations, consider adding sidewalks and bicycle accommodations
along Leo Birmingham Parkway if a road diet is implemented.
9. As part of long-term design considerations, consider converting one side of Leo Birmingham Parkway
to a two-lane, two-way roadway, and converting the north side of Leo Birmingham Parkway into a
reserved space for pedestrian and bicycle travel. This concept could be tested using temporary materials
10. As part of long-term design efforts, consider a “placemaking” effort under the I-90 overpass, similar
to other efforts in the South End of Boston and along McGrath Highway in Somerville. Such engagement
with the community may encourage more pedestrian and bicycle activity through the area, and the public
may share additional insight as to a long-term design for the intersection of Leo Birmingham
Road Safety Audit—Leo Birmingham Parkway at North Beacon Street, Brighton

text.b: at the intersection, but it is non-
standard and difficult to locate due to

page.text: There is limited wayfinding signage in the vicinity of the intersection. Wayfinding signage for Route 20
is provided along North Beacon Street northbound approach
and along the Leo Birmingham Parkway westbound. The
sign located on Leo Birmingham Parkway westbound is non-
standard, and may be difficult to see for oncoming traffic.
The sign on the North Beacon Street northbound approach to
the intersection is located at the end of the I-90 bridge
overpass, and may be difficult to see as vehicles drive under
the overpass. The stop sign in the same location as this guide
sign is similarly difficult to see.
There is no lane use signage along the North Beacon Street
northbound approach to the intersection. The lack of signage
may contribute to motorists’ tendency to form three travel
lanes as they approach the intersection.
There is also no guide signage along any approach to the intersection indicating the best way to reach
other key, nearby roadways, such as Solder’s Field Road or I-90. There are also no street name signs at
the intersection. A lack of guide signage may contribute to the high numbers of crashes observed
involving 21 to 29-year-olds, and crashes in September, as students from out of the area attempt to drive
through the area as they return to school.
There is also a lack of pedestrian and bicycle-scale guide signage. While pedestrian signage may not be
provided as pedestrians are not intended to walk through the intersection, bicyclists looking to travel
between the Dr. Paul Dudley White Bike Path and the rest of the Brighton neighborhood may benefit
1. Provide standard advanced wayfinding signage for Route 20 along Leo Birmingham Parkway and
along North Beacon Street northbound. Advanced signage on Leo Birmingham Parkway should allow
vehicles to safely change lanes in order to make the turn onto North Beacon Street. Advanced signage on
North Beacon Street should be placed ahead of the I-90 bridge overpass to ensure visibility.
2. Place a Stop Ahead (W3-1) sign in advance of the I-90 bridge overpass on North Beacon Street to
warn motorists that they must stop in advance of the intersection. This enhancement would address some
of the angle crashes involving Leo Birmingham Parkway eastbound vehicles and North Beacon Street
3. Place intersection warning signage (W2-2) in advance of the intersection on the Leo Birmingham
Parkway eastbound and westbound approaches to the intersection to warn oncoming motorists that traffic
Road Safety Audit—Leo Birmingham Parkway at North Beacon Street, Brighton

text.b: travel under an overpass just before

page.text: 4. Place diagrammatic lane use signage (R3-8, etc.) in advance of the I-90 bridge overpass on the North
Beacon Street northbound approach so that vehicles may form the appropriate lanes in advance of the
5. Consider placing guide signage along Leo Birmingham Parkway and along the North Beacon Street
northbound approach, in advance of the I-90 bridge overpass, to help guide motorists through the area.
Place street name signage (D3-1 and/or D3-2) at all legs of the intersection.
6. Consider placing pedestrian- and bicycle-scale guide signage at the intersection to help guide
pedestrians and bicyclists through the area. Consider the safety implications of providing this signage
before more substantive improvements to the pedestrian and bicycling environment have been made.
On the North Beacon Street northbound approach to the
intersection, there is no lighting under the I-90 overpass,
causing vehicles to reach the stop line just after emerging
from the overpass. The differences in light make it difficult
to perceive signage and other information; objects in the light
are difficult to see while under the overpass, and objects
under the overpass may be difficult to see while in the light.
As previously discussed, two signs are located just north of
the overpass that are difficult to see while under the overpass
The light differences may also make it difficult to see
pedestrians, bicyclists, other vehicles, signs, and pavement
markings in or near the intersection. Motorists’ eyes need
time to adjust from light to dark and from dark to light.
During the RSA, there were lights installed within the underpass; however, they were not functioning.
An RSA team member stated that these lights are likely supposed to work only during the day, as there is
a smaller difference in ambient light during the nighttime.
Seven crashes (20%) occurred during the nighttime hours. While the crash reports indicate that the
roadway is lighted, RSA team members stated that lighting may not be sufficient.
1. In the short-term, fix the light fixtures under the I-90 overpass to ensure that North Beacon Street
northbound approach under the overpass is lit in order for motorists to see other vehicles, pedestrians,
bicyclists, signage, and other objects under the underpass.
2. Consider the need for additional lighting at the intersection. Consider that additional lighting may
become increasingly necessary if a formalized pedestrian crossing is provided at the intersection
especially if such a crossing is unsignalized.
Road Safety Audit—Leo Birmingham Parkway at North Beacon Street, Brighton
Table 2 below shows the estimated time frames of short-term, mid-term, and long-term solutions, as well
as the cost ranges of low-cost, medium-cost, and high-cost projects. Table 3 provides an estimate of the
timeframe and cost of each potential safety issue that may address each of the identified safety issues.
Table 2: Estimated Time Frame and Costs Breakdown
Road Safety Audit—Leo Birmingham Parkway at North Beacon Street, Brighton
In the short term, consider striping lane use pavement markings
on North Beacon Street to organize vehicles into a single left-
turn lane and a single right-turn lane. Work with Eversource to
conduct this work once current utility work is complete.
If lane lanes are striped on the North Beacon Street northbound
approach to the intersection, consider the use of dashed lane
lines through the intersection from North Beacon Street
northbound to Leo Birmingham Parkway eastbound and
westbound so that vehicles can be guided through the
intersection and to discourage the formation of multiple left-turn
lanes on the North Beacon Street northbound approach.
Consider the safety benefits of enhancing the existing flashing
operation at the intersection to increase visibility and awareness
If at least one signal warrant is met, consider a full signalization
of the intersection to eliminate “courtesy crashes” and the need
for North Beacon Street northbound vehicles to look for gaps in
two lanes of traffic in either direction. Consider the potential
drawbacks of signalization, which may include the persistence of
angle crashes and an increase in rear-end crashes. Consider
the costs, safety benefits, and drawbacks of signalization
compared to other enhancements, such as a modern
roundabout. If the intersection is fully signalized, retroreflective
backplates should be used to minimize the effects of solar glare
on motorists. A “(Red) Signal Ahead” (W3-3) sign, with
illuminated “Red” text when the signal is red, should be
considered in advance of the I-90 overpass on the North Beacon
Street northbound approach, and supplemental signal posts
should be placed at the end of the approach.

appropriate striping and advanced signage, to reduce the
instances of rear-end and single-vehicle crashes as a result of
vehicles unexpectedly slowing to turn at the intersection. If
exclusive turn lanes are implemented, consider modifications to
the median and/or shoulders to prevent through movements

intersection. This improvement would formalize the prevailing
movements at the intersection as “through” movements which
would not need to yield at the intersection. It should be noted
that the commercial service road north of the intersection is
within the DCR layout, and not privately owned.

currently rely on the roadway. Consider parallel roads, including
Soldier’s Field Road and Interstate 90, which may render Leo
Birmingham Parkway unnecessary to carry significant volumes

would address some of the angle crashes involving Leo

ensure that North Beacon Street northbound approach under the
overpass is lit in order for motorists to see other vehicles,
pedestrians, bicyclists, signage, and other objects under the
underpass. Lighting should illuminate the roadway under the
underpass during the daytime to improve visibility of signage
and pavement markings under the underpass.
Consider the need for additional lighting at the intersection.
Consider that additional lighting may become increasingly
necessary if a formalized pedestrian crossing is provided at the
intersection especially if such a crossing is unsignalized.

text.b: Leo M. Birmingham Parkway/North Beacon Street
Meeting Location: WGBH, Reno Conference Room (3
High Crash Location – Road Safety Audit

page.text:  Crash history, Speed Regulations – provided in advance
 Walk to the intersections of Leo M. Birmingham Parkway/North Beacon Street
 As a group, identify areas for improvement
 Discuss observations and finalize safety issue areas
 Discuss potential improvements and finalize recommendations

text.b: Adjourn for the Day – but the RSA has not ended

page.text:  Before attending the RSA on May 19th, participants are encouraged to drive/walk

text.b: through the intersection and complete/consider elements on the RSA Prompt List

page.text:  All participants will be actively involved in the process throughout. Participants

text.b: are encouraged to come with thoughts and ideas, but are reminded that the
synergy that develops and respect for others’ opinions are key elements to the
success of the overall RSA process.

page.text:  After the RSA meeting, participants will be asked to comment and respond to the
